title: NK Maribor in European football
text:
<a href="NK%20Maribor">Nogometni klub Maribor</a>, also simply known as NK Maribor, is a Slovenian professional <a href="association%20football">football club</a> based in <a href="Maribor">Maribor</a>. The club have participated in 36 editions of the club competitions governed by the <a href="Union%20of%20European%20Football%20Associations">Union of European Football Associations</a> (UEFA), the chief authority for football across Europe. These include 15 seasons in the <a href="UEFA%20Champions%20League">UEFA Champions League</a>, 15 seasons in the <a href="UEFA%20Europa%20League">UEFA Cup and Europa League</a>, one season in the <a href="UEFA%20Europa%20Conference%20League">UEFA Europa Conference League</a>, two seasons in the <a href="UEFA%20Cup%20Winners%27%20Cup">UEFA Cup Winners' Cup</a>, and three seasons in the <a href="UEFA%20Intertoto%20Cup">UEFA Intertoto Cup</a>. Counting all of the 171 games the side have played in European competitions since their first entry into the <a href="Mitropa%20Cup">Mitropa Cup</a> in the <a href="1970%E2%80%9371%20Mitropa%20Cup">1970–71</a> season, the team's record stands at 63 wins, 41 draws, and 67 defeats as of match played 29 July 2021. The club's most recent participation in a continental competition was in the 2021–22 season, when they played in the qualifying rounds of the <a href="2021%E2%80%9322%20UEFA%20Europa%20Conference%20League">2021–22 UEFA Europa Conference League</a>.
Maribor's 10–0 victory over <a href="FC%20Norma%20Tallinn">Norma Tallinn</a> of Estonia in the <a href="1994%E2%80%9395%20UEFA%20Cup%20Winners%27%20Cup">1994–95 UEFA Cup Winners' Cup</a> is the club's most decisive win in European competitions, while the team's heaviest defeat is 9–1, against the Dutch club <a href="AFC%20Ajax">Ajax</a> in the <a href="1997%E2%80%9398%20UEFA%20Cup">1997–98 UEFA Cup</a>. With 94 caps, <a href="Marcos%20Tavares">Marcos Tavares</a> has appeared in the most UEFA matches for Maribor; Tavares has also scored the most goals with 31.
As of the 2021–22 season, Maribor is the only Slovenian club that has managed to qualify for the group stages of the UEFA Champions League, and one of five clubs from the former <a href="Socialist%20Federal%20Republic%20of%20Yugoslavia">Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia</a> who have participated in the group stages of the competition since the breakup of the country in 1992. Maribor won their only European honour in 2006, when they defeated <a href="Villarreal%20CF">Villarreal</a> in the third round of the <a href="2006%20UEFA%20Intertoto%20Cup">2006 UEFA Intertoto Cup</a>, becoming one of the eleven co-winners of the competition.
Background.
Club competitions between teams from European countries can trace their origins as far back as 1897, when the <a href="Challenge%20Cup%20%28Austro-Hungarian%20Empire%29">Challenge Cup</a> was created for clubs in the Austro-Hungarian Empire. The <a href="Mitropa%20Cup">Mitropa Cup</a>, a competition modelled after the Challenge Cup, was created in 1927 and played between Central European clubs. The first continental competition organised by <a href="UEFA">UEFA</a> was the <a href="UEFA%20Champions%20League">European Cup</a> in 1955. Established as a competition for winners of the European national football leagues, it is considered the most prestigious European football competition. The European Cup was re-branded in 1992 as the UEFA Champions League. In the 1950s, two further competitions were created: the <a href="Inter-Cities%20Fairs%20Cup">Inter-Cities Fairs Cup</a> and <a href="UEFA%20Cup%20Winners%27%20Cup">UEFA Cup Winners' Cup</a>. Established in 1955, the Inter-Cities Fairs Cup was later re-branded as the <a href="UEFA%20Cup">UEFA Cup</a> when it came under the auspices of UEFA in 1971. Since the 2009–10 season, the competition has been known as the UEFA Europa League. The UEFA Cup Winners' Cup was inaugurated in 1960 for the winners of domestic cup competitions.
History.
Yugoslav period: 1960–1991.
Before Slovenia's independence in 1991, Maribor competed in the <a href="Yugoslav%20football%20league%20system">Yugoslav football league system</a>. When playing in the <a href="Yugoslav%20First%20League">Yugoslav First League</a>, Maribor never finished in positions which assured competing in UEFA competitions; the closest they came was in the <a href="1969%E2%80%9370%20Yugoslav%20First%20League">1969–70</a> season, when they finished tenth. Maribor made its debut in European competitions in the <a href="1970%E2%80%9371%20Mitropa%20Cup">1970–71</a> season, when it competed in the <a href="Mitropa%20Cup">Mitropa Cup</a>, a non-UEFA competition for Central European teams. Maribor were eliminated in the first round by the Austrian side <a href="Grazer%20AK">Grazer AK</a> on <a href="away%20goals%20rule">away goals rule</a>, having won 3–1 at home and lost 2–0 away.
New country and UEFA debut: 1992–1996.
After the <a href="breakup%20of%20Yugoslavia">breakup of Yugoslavia</a>, the <a href="Football%20Association%20of%20Slovenia">Football Association of Slovenia</a> established their own competitions. Maribor were the inaugural winners of the <a href="Slovenian%20Football%20Cup">Slovenian Cup</a>, where they defeated their <a href="Eternal%20derby%20of%20Slovenian%20football%20%281962%E2%80%932004%29">biggest rivals</a> <a href="NK%20Olimpija%20Ljubljana%20%281945%29">Olimpija</a> in the <a href="1991%E2%80%9392%20Slovenian%20Football%20Cup%23Final">final</a>. As the national cup winners, they qualified for the <a href="1992%E2%80%9393%20European%20Cup%20Winners%27%20Cup">1992–93 European Cup Winners' Cup</a>. In the qualifying round, they played against <a href="%C4%A6amrun%20Spartans%20F.C.">Ħamrun Spartans</a> from Malta. The first match was played on 19 August 1992 at <a href="Ljudski%20vrt">Ljudski vrt</a>, where Maribor won 4–0. This was the first ever match for Maribor in the official UEFA competitions. Fourteen days later they lost the second leg 2–1, but still managed to qualify for the first round with an <a href="Two-legged%20tie">aggregate</a> score of 5–2. In the first round, they were drawn against the Spanish side <a href="Atl%C3%A9tico%20Madrid">Atlético Madrid</a>. Maribor lost the first leg 3–0 at the home turf in front of 8,000 spectators, and later suffered a heavy defeat in the second leg in <a href="Madrid">Madrid</a>, where Atlético won 6–1. In the next season, Maribor played in the <a href="UEFA%20Europa%20League">UEFA Cup</a> for the first time. They reached the second round, where they were eliminated by <a href="Borussia%20Dortmund">Borussia Dortmund</a>, 2–1 on aggregate. On 25 August 1994, Maribor played a historic game against <a href="FC%20Norma%20Tallinn">Norma Tallinn</a> from Estonia in the Cup Winners' Cup. This was the first match at Ljudski vrt under the floodlights, and also the biggest ever victory for Maribor in European competitions (10–0). In 1996, Maribor competed in the group stage of the <a href="1996%20UEFA%20Intertoto%20Cup">1996 UEFA Intertoto Cup</a>. They defeated <a href="FK%20Austria%20Wien">Austria Wien</a> 3–0 at home in the first round, but in the next three games, they only managed to get one point, against <a href="Keflav%C3%ADk%20Football%20Club">Keflavík</a>. Maribor lost the remaining two matches against two Scandinavian teams, <a href="F.C.%20Copenhagen">København</a> and <a href="%C3%96rebro%20SK">Örebro</a>, and finished in third place with four points.
Champions League: 1997–1999.
In the <a href="1996%E2%80%9397%20Slovenian%20PrvaLiga">1996–97</a> season, Maribor won the national league for the first time. As the Slovenian champions, they started in the second qualifying round of the <a href="1997%E2%80%9398%20UEFA%20Champions%20League">1997–98 Champions League</a>, where they eliminated <a href="Derry%20City%20F.C.">Derry City</a> from Ireland. In the last qualifying round before the group stages, they were drawn against the Turkish side <a href="Be%C5%9Fikta%C5%9F%20J.K.">Beşiktaş</a>. Beşiktaş did not manage to win the first game at their own ground, as the game ended 0–0. However, Maribor lost the home leg 3–1 and were eliminated. They continued their European journey in the UEFA Cup, where they were eliminated by <a href="AFC%20Ajax">Ajax</a>. The first game in Maribor ended with 1–1. In the return leg in <a href="Amsterdam">Amsterdam</a>, Maribor suffered their heaviest defeat in the European football, as Ajax won the match 9–1. In the next season, Maribor came very close to the group stages. After eliminating <a href="FK%20Kareda%20Kaunas">Kareda Šiauliai</a> in the second qualifying round, they again reached the last qualifying round before the group stages. This time, they were drawn against another Dutch side, <a href="PSV%20Eindhoven">PSV Eindhoven</a>. At Ljudski vrt, Peter Breznik scored in the 83rd minute for 2–1, and gave Maribor one goal advantage before visiting the <a href="Philips%20Stadion">Philips Stadion</a> in <a href="Eindhoven">Eindhoven</a>. In the second leg, <a href="Dalibor%20Filipovi%C4%87">Dalibor Filipović</a> scored in the fifth minute to give Maribor a 1–0 lead, but PSV responded immediately and equalised in the ninth minute. PSV scored another goal half an hour before the end, and the match went to <a href="Overtime%20%28sports%29">extra time</a>. Maribor eventually lost the game 4–2 and were eliminated. Again, they continued in the UEFA Cup, and as in the previous season were eliminated in the first round, this time by <a href="Wis%C5%82a%20Krak%C3%B3w">Wisła Kraków</a>, losing both games.
In the 1999–2000 season, Maribor finally reached the group stages of the elite UEFA Champions League. They started their European triumph with a 5–1 home win against <a href="K.R.C.%20Genk">Racing Genk</a> in the second qualifying round. In the second leg in Belgium, Genk were leading 3–0 and Maribor were down to ten players as <a href="Amir%20Kari%C4%87">Amir Karić</a> was sent off, but the team managed to hold on and advanced 5–4 on aggregate. In the third qualifying round, Maribor faced <a href="Olympique%20Lyonnais">Olympique Lyonnais</a>. In the first leg in France, Filipović scored the only goal of the match two minutes before full-time. The demand for tickets for the second leg was so high that dozens of fans waited in line all night in front of the stadium to secure their tickets, as the capacity of the stadium at the time was only 7,500. In the second leg, Maribor defeated the French side 2–0, with goals from <a href="Ante%20%C5%A0imund%C5%BEa">Ante Šimundža</a> and <a href="Stipe%20Balaji%C4%87">Stipe Balajić</a> in the first half, and the club reached the group stages for the first time.
Maribor played in Group A with <a href="Bayer%2004%20Leverkusen">Bayer Leverkusen</a>, <a href="FC%20Dynamo%20Kyiv">Dynamo Kyiv</a>, and <a href="S.S.%20Lazio">Lazio</a>. In the first round, Maribor defeated Dynamo 1–0 in <a href="Kyiv">Kyiv</a> and topped the table; Šimundža became the first goal scorer for Maribor in the Champions League group stage after scoring in the 72nd minute. In the second round, Maribor lost 2–0 at home to Bayer Leverkusen; both goals were scored in the last eight minutes. Lazio then defeated Maribor twice, in the third and the fourth round. Both matches ended 4–0 for the Italian team. In the fifth round, Maribor lost 2–1 to Dynamo at home. In the final round, Maribor prevented Bayer from qualifying to the further stages; the match ended in a goalless draw, while Bayer needed a win to secure the second place in the group. Maribor were eliminated from the competition, finishing in the fourth and last place with four points.
Decline and Intertoto success: 2000–2008.
In each of the next four seasons, Maribor were eliminated in the second qualifying round of the Champions League. The decline of the club in European competitions started in the <a href="2000%E2%80%9301%20UEFA%20Champions%20League">2000–01</a> season, when Maribor were surprisingly knocked out of the Champions League in the second qualifying round by <a href="FC%20Zimbru%20Chi%C5%9Fin%C4%83u">Zimbru Chişinău</a> from Moldova. Maribor lost the first leg 2–0. In the return leg, <a href="Nastja%20%C4%8Ceh">Nastja Čeh</a> scored the only goal of the game in the third minute, and Zimbru eliminated Maribor 2–1 on aggregate. In the <a href="2001%E2%80%9302%20UEFA%20Champions%20League">2001–02</a> season, Maribor were drawn against the Scottish side <a href="Rangers%20F.C.">Rangers</a>. The tie was already decided after the first match in Maribor, where Rangers won 3–0. In the second leg, Maribor took the lead at <a href="Ibrox%20Stadium">Ibrox Stadium</a> in <a href="Glasgow">Glasgow</a>, but Rangers then scored three times for 3–1, eliminating Maribor 6–1 on aggregate. In the <a href="2002%E2%80%9303%20UEFA%20Champions%20League">2002–03</a> season, Maribor were eliminated by <a href="APOEL%20F.C.">APOEL</a>. The first match in Maribor ended 2–1 for the home side, but APOEL won the return leg 4–2 in Cyprus, and Maribor were again eliminated in the second qualifying round. In the next year, they were eliminated by <a href="GNK%20Dinamo%20Zagreb">Dinamo Zagreb</a>, 3–2 on aggregate. The match in Maribor ended 1–1, while in the second leg in <a href="Zagreb">Zagreb</a>, the Croatian champions won 2–1 and advanced to the third qualifying round.
In the <a href="2003%E2%80%9304%20Slovenian%20PrvaLiga">2003–04</a> season, Maribor failed to win the national title for the first time since 1996, and therefore competed in the UEFA Cup for the <a href="2004%E2%80%9305%20UEFA%20Cup">2004–05</a> season. They reached the first round, but were stopped by <a href="Parma%20F.C.">Parma</a>. To reach the first round, Maribor eliminated <a href="FK%20Sileks">Sileks</a> from Macedonia and <a href="FK%20Budu%C4%87nost%20Banatski%20Dvor">Budućnost Banatski Dvor</a> from Serbia and Montenegro in the qualifying stages. Maribor did not qualify for European competitions for the 2005–06 season, having previously appeared in Europe in every season since the independence of Slovenia in 1991.
Maribor have returned to European football in the 2006–07 season, when the team won its first European honour, becoming one of the eleven co-winners of the <a href="2006%20UEFA%20Intertoto%20Cup">2006 UEFA Intertoto Cup</a>. In the first round, Maribor defeated <a href="UE%20Sant%20Juli%C3%A0">Sant Julià</a> from Andorra, before eliminating <a href="FK%20Zeta">Zeta</a> who competed under the flag of newly established Montenegro. In the last round, Maribor played against <a href="Villarreal%20CF">Villarreal</a>. The Spanish side played in the <a href="2005%E2%80%9306%20UEFA%20Champions%20League">semi-finals</a> of the Champions League just four months before the match between the two sides took place. In the first match in Spain, <a href="Rene%20Miheli%C4%8D">Rene Mihelič</a> scored in the 83rd minute for a 2–1 win. Ljudski vrt was filled with fans in the second leg, as 9,500 people gathered to see the match. Villarreal, who had three players sent off during the game, took the lead in the 85th minute, but <a href="Gorazd%20Zajc">Gorazd Zajc</a> equalized just four minutes later to make it 3–2 on aggregate. On their official website, UEFA states that Maribor were one of the winners of the competition. However, the trophy itself was awarded to <a href="Newcastle%20United%20F.C.">Newcastle United</a>, the team that advanced the farthest in the UEFA Cup in that season. As one of the winners of the Intertoto Cup, Maribor continued their European campaign in the UEFA Cup, where they were eliminated by <a href="FK%20Partizan">Partizan</a> in the second qualifying round.
In the next season, Maribor again competed in the <a href="2007%20UEFA%20Intertoto%20Cup">Intertoto Cup</a>. In the second round of the competition, the team lost 5–0 in the second leg against <a href="FK%20Hajduk%20Kula">Hajduk Kula</a> after winning the first match 2–0, being eliminated 5–2 on aggregate. After losing the <a href="2007%E2%80%9308%20Slovenian%20Cup">2007–08 Slovenian Cup</a> final to <a href="NK%20Interblock">Interblock</a>, Maribor lost their place in European competitions for the 2008–09 season.
Zlatko Zahovič era: 2008–2020.
Maribor's Director of Football, <a href="Zlatko%20Zahovi%C4%8D">Zlatko Zahovič</a>, appointed <a href="Darko%20Milani%C4%8D">Darko Milanič</a> as the new manager in May 2008. In his first season, Maribor won the <a href="2008%E2%80%9309%20Slovenian%20PrvaLiga">league</a> title for the first time since 2003. In the <a href="2009%E2%80%9310%20UEFA%20Champions%20League">2009–10 UEFA Champions League</a>, Maribor started in the second qualifying round against <a href="FC%20WIT%20Georgia">WIT</a> from Georgia. The first match away from home ended scoreless. Maribor confirmed their spot in the third qualifying round at Ljudski vrt, where they won 3–1. They next played <a href="FC%20Z%C3%BCrich">Zürich</a>, and unexpectedly won the first match 3–2 at <a href="Letzigrund">Letzigrund</a>; <a href="Zoran%20Pavlovi%C4%87">Zoran Pavlović</a> scored the third goal directly from a <a href="corner%20kick">corner kick</a> and later missed a <a href="Penalty%20kick%20%28association%20football%29">penalty</a>. 12,000 fans gathered for the second leg, where Maribor lost 3–0 and were eliminated. Maribor continued in the <a href="UEFA%20Europa%20League">Europa League</a> play-offs, but were eliminated by <a href="AC%20Sparta%20Prague">Sparta Prague</a> 3–0 on aggregate. In the <a href="2010%E2%80%9311%20NK%20Maribor%20season">2010–11</a> season, Maribor reached the play-offs of the UEFA <a href="2010%E2%80%9311%20UEFA%20Europa%20League">Europa League</a>. After eliminating Hungarian team <a href="Videoton%20FC">Videoton</a> and <a href="Hibernian%20F.C.">Hibernian</a> from Scotland. In the play-off round, Maribor played against <a href="U.S.%20Citt%C3%A0%20di%20Palermo">Palermo</a>. The Italian side won the first leg 3–0 at the <a href="Stadio%20Renzo%20Barbera">Stadio Renzo Barbera</a>, while Maribor won the second leg 3–2, but were eliminated 5–3 on aggregate. <a href="Josip%20Ili%C4%8Di%C4%87">Josip Iličić</a>, who scored three goals during the European campaign, and <a href="Armin%20Ba%C4%8Dinovi%C4%87">Armin Bačinović</a> both transferred to Palermo just one day after the match.
In the <a href="2011%E2%80%9312%20NK%20Maribor%20season">2011–12</a> season, Maribor managed to reach the group stages of the Europa League for the first time. As the Slovenian <a href="2010%E2%80%9311%20Slovenian%20PrvaLiga">champions</a>, they entered in the <a href="2011%E2%80%9312%20UEFA%20Champions%20League%23Third%20second%20round">second qualifying round</a> of the Champions League, where they defeated <a href="F91%20Dudelange">F91 Dudelange</a>, winning both games with 5–1 on aggregate. Maribor were once again stopped in the third qualifying round, this time by <a href="Maccabi%20Haifa%20F.C.">Maccabi Haifa</a>, losing 3–2 on aggregate. For the Europa League play-offs, they were drawn against Rangers. At Ljudski vrt, Rangers were leading 1–0 after the first half, with <a href="Agim%20Ibraimi">Agim Ibraimi</a> equalising early in the second half. <a href="Etien%20Velikonja">Etien Velikonja</a> scored the winning goal in extra time to give Maribor a win before the trip to Glasgow for the second leg. In the second leg, Rangers had 10 attempts on target and 13 off target, in addition to 16 corners. Still, Maribor managed to take the lead in the 55th minute, when <a href="Dalibor%20Vola%C5%A1">Dalibor Volaš</a> scored. Fifteen minutes before the end, Rangers equalised, but Maribor managed to hold on and eliminated Rangers 3–2 on aggregate. In the Europa League group stage, Maribor were drawn against the runners-up of the <a href="2010%E2%80%9311%20UEFA%20Europa%20League">2010–11</a> edition <a href="S.C.%20Braga">Braga</a>, the <a href="2010%E2%80%9311%20Football%20League%20Cup">2010–11 Football League Cup</a> winners <a href="Birmingham%20City%20F.C.">Birmingham City</a>, and <a href="Club%20Brugge%20K.V.">Club Brugge</a>. They lost five out of six games, only managing to draw with Braga at home. In the <a href="2012%E2%80%9313%20NK%20Maribor%20season">next season</a>, Maribor reached the play-offs of the Champions League for the first time since the <a href="1999%E2%80%932000%20UEFA%20Champions%20League">1999–2000</a> season, but were eliminated by Dinamo Zagreb, 3–1 on aggregate. Maribor qualified for the Europa League group stages as one of the losers in the Champions League play-offs. This time, they managed to get four points, beating <a href="Panathinaikos%20F.C.">Panathinaikos</a> and drawing with <a href="Tottenham%20Hotspur%20F.C.">Tottenham Hotspur</a>, both at Ljudski vrt. They lost both games against Lazio.
Maribor started their <a href="2013%E2%80%9314%20NK%20Maribor%20season">2013–14</a> European campaign in the second qualifying round of the <a href="2013%E2%80%9314%20UEFA%20Champions%20League">2013–14 UEFA Champions League</a> with a 2–0 aggregate victory over <a href="Birkirkara%20F.C.">Birkirkara</a> from Malta. In the third qualifying round, Maribor eliminated APOEL on away goals rule, securing their place in the play-off round for the second season in a row. However, Maribor once again lost in the play-off round and continued their European season in the group stages of the Europa League for the third time in a row. On 19 September 2013, the team played its first match in the group stage of the Europa League and were defeated by the Russian side <a href="FC%20Rubin%20Kazan">Rubin Kazan</a>. On 24 October 2013, Maribor defeated <a href="Zulte%20Waregem">Zulte Waregem</a> 3–1 in Belgium, securing their first ever away victory in the Europa League group stages. On 12 December 2013, Maribor defeated <a href="Wigan%20Athletic%20F.C.">Wigan Athletic</a> 2–1 and qualified for the Europa League Round of 32 for the first time, finishing in the second place with seven points out of six games. In the Round of 32, Maribor played in a two-legged tie against the Spanish side <a href="Sevilla%20F.C.">Sevilla</a> (who later won the competition) and lost 3–2 on aggregate.
After unsuccessful attempts in the previous two seasons, Maribor finally reached the group stages of the Champions League in the <a href="2014%E2%80%9315%20NK%20Maribor%20season">2014–15</a> season. Led by former Maribor player Ante Šimundža, they eliminated <a href="H%C5%A0K%20Zrinjski%20Mostar">Zrinjski Mostar</a>, <a href="Maccabi%20Tel%20Aviv%20F.C.">Maccabi Tel Aviv</a>, and <a href="Celtic%20F.C.">Celtic</a> in the <a href="2014%E2%80%9315%20UEFA%20Champions%20League%20qualifying%20phase%20and%20play-off%20round">qualifying phase</a>. Maribor had previously qualified for the group stages only once, in the 1999–2000 season. They were drawn in <a href="2014%E2%80%9315%20UEFA%20Champions%20League%20group%20stage">Group G</a> with <a href="Chelsea%20F.C.">Chelsea</a>, <a href="FC%20Schalke%2004">Schalke 04</a>, and <a href="Sporting%20Clube%20de%20Portugal">Sporting CP</a>. They managed to obtain three points in six games after a draw and a defeat against each team. In the <a href="2015%E2%80%9316%20NK%20Maribor%20season">2015–16</a> season, Maribor were eliminated from European competitions after only two matches as the team were eliminated by <a href="FC%20Astana">Astana</a> in the <a href="2015%E2%80%9316%20UEFA%20Champions%20League%23Second%20qualifying%20round">second qualifying round</a> of the Champions League, meaning the club failed to advance to the third qualifying round of the competition for the first time since the 2003–04 season. After failing to win the Slovenian League for the first time since 2009–10, Maribor qualified for the <a href="2016%E2%80%9317%20UEFA%20Europa%20League">2016–17 UEFA Europa League</a> second qualifying round as the Slovenian Cup <a href="2015%E2%80%9316%20Slovenian%20Football%20Cup%23Final">winners</a>, where they were drawn against Bulgarian team <a href="PFC%20Levski%20Sofia">Levski Sofia</a>. After a goalless draw in the first leg at home, Maribor eliminated Levski on the away goals rule with an aggregate score of 1–1. Maribor defeated <a href="Aberdeen%20F.C.">Aberdeen</a> in the third qualifying round 2–1 on aggregate, and were eliminated in the play-off round by <a href="Gabala%20FC">Gabala</a> 3–2 on aggregate.
After one season of absence in the Champions League, Maribor won the national title again in the <a href="2016%E2%80%9317%20Slovenian%20PrvaLiga">2016–17</a> season, and started their European campaign in the second qualifying round of the <a href="2017%E2%80%9318%20UEFA%20Champions%20League">2017–18 UEFA Champions League</a>. They were drawn against Zrinjski, whom they had previously played in 2014–15. Maribor won the first leg in <a href="Mostar">Mostar</a> 2–1, with <a href="Marcos%20Tavares">Marcos Tavares</a> scoring the winning goal in the 94th minute, and drew the second leg 1–1 at home to reach the third qualifying round. Tavares scored two more goals in the third qualifying round in a 2–0 aggregate victory over <a href="Fimleikaf%C3%A9lag%20Hafnarfjar%C3%B0ar">FH</a>, helping Maribor to qualify for the play-off stage for the fourth time in six seasons. In the play-offs, Maribor eliminated Israeli side <a href="Hapoel%20Be%27er%20Sheva%20F.C.">Hapoel Be'er-Sheva</a> on away goals, after losing the first match 2–1 in Israel and winning the return leg 1–0 at home with a goal scored by <a href="Mitja%20Viler">Mitja Viler</a>. Maribor had previously qualified for the group stage of the competition in the 1999–2000 and 2014–15 seasons. Maribor competed in Group E, along with <a href="FC%20Spartak%20Moscow">Spartak Moscow</a>, Sevilla, and <a href="Liverpool%20F.C.">Liverpool</a>. As in the 2014–15 season, the club obtained three points in six matches after drawing with Sevilla at home and against Spartak twice with all three matches finishing 1–1. Their 7–0 defeat to Liverpool in the third match was the club's heaviest home defeat in European competitions, and their second highest European defeat overall.
Maribor's 2018–19 European campaign ended in the <a href="2018%E2%80%9319%20UEFA%20Europa%20League%23Third%20qualifying%20round">third qualifying round</a> of the Europa League, where Maribor were eliminated by Rangers, 3–1 on aggregate. After winning their 15th national title in 2019, Maribor competed in the Champions League again in the <a href="2019%E2%80%9320%20UEFA%20Champions%20League">2019–20 season</a>. After eliminating <a href="Valur%20men%27s%20football">Valur</a> and <a href="AIK%20Fotboll">AIK</a> in the first two qualifying rounds, the team was stopped in the third qualifying round by <a href="Rosenborg%20BK">Rosenborg</a>, losing both games with a score of 3–1. Maribor were also eliminated by <a href="PFC%20Ludogorets%20Razgrad">Ludogorets Razgrad</a> in the Europa League <a href="2019%E2%80%9320%20UEFA%20Europa%20League%23Play-off%20round">play-offs</a>. In March 2020, Zahovič resigned as Maribor's Director of Football; in his 13 years with the club, Maribor experienced its most successful period in European football, reaching the Europa League group stages three times and the Champions League group stages twice. In the <a href="2020%E2%80%9321%20UEFA%20Europa%20League">2020–21 UEFA Europa League</a>, Maribor were surprisingly eliminated in the <a href="2020%E2%80%9321%20UEFA%20Europa%20League%20qualifying%20phase%20and%20play-off%20round%23First%20qualifying%20round">first qualifying round</a> by the semi-professional Northern Irish team <a href="Coleraine%20F.C.">Coleraine</a> on <a href="Penalty%20shoot-out%20%28association%20football%29">penalties</a>, which led to the dismissal of manager <a href="Sergej%20Jakirovi%C4%87">Sergej Jakirović</a>.

UEFA coefficient.
In European football, the UEFA coefficients are statistics used for ranking and <a href="Single-elimination%20tournament%23Seeding">seeding</a> teams in club and international competitions. The table shows the position of Maribor, based on their UEFA coefficient club ranking, and four clubs, which are closest to Maribor's position (the two clubs with the higher coefficient and the two with the lower coefficient).
